holdings.text: the arbitration agreement executed by the parties on December 30, 1943, is invalid under s. 23 of the Indian Contract Act, because its consideration was opposed to public policy.
holdings.reasoning_summary: Evidence establishes consideration was promise to withdraw criminal complaint for non-compoundable offences; such stifling prosecution opposed to public policy under s.23; lower courts erred in assessment.

holdings.text: the consideration for the agreement of reference in the present case was the withdrawal and non-prosecution of the criminal complaint filed by respondent No. 1.
holdings.reasoning_summary: Sequence of events, witness testimonies (Sitharamaswamy, Jayachandra Padhi, Appa Rao, appellant), clause 5 linking costs, ambiguity in respondent's evidence support finding; lower courts failed to properly weigh evidence.

holdings.text: If it is shown that the consideration for the arbitration agreement was the withdrawal and the non-prosecution of the criminal complaint, then the provisions of s. 23 of the Indian Contract Act would be attracted.

precedents.citation: Sudhindra Kumar v. Ganesh Chandra 1 [1939 I Cal. 241, 250]

anchor.surface_text: Sudhindra Kumar v. Ganesh Chandra 1  numberCourt of law can companyntenance or give effect an agreement which attempts to take the administration of law out of the hands of the judges and put in the hands of private individuals.

precedents.cited_proposition: No court of law can countenance or give effect to an agreement which attempts to take the administration of law out of the hands of the judges and put it in the hands of private individuals
precedents.cited_holding: numberCourt of law can companyntenance or give effect an agreement which attempts to take the administration of law out of the hands of the judges and put in the hands of private individuals.

precedents.citation: Bhowanipur Banking Corporation Lid. v. Sreemati Durgesh Nandini Dasi 2 [A.I.R. 1941 P.C. 95]

anchor.surface_text: in Bhowanipur Banking Corporation Lid. v. Sreemati Durgesh Nandini Dasi 2  Lord Atkin has observed  1  1939 I Cal. 241, 250.  2  A.I.R. 1941 P.C. 95. that to insist on reparation as a companysideration for promise to abandon criminal proceedings is a, serious abuse of the right of private prosecution.

precedents.case_name: Bhowanipur Banking Corporation Ltd. v. Sreemati Durgesh Nandini Dasi
precedents.cited_proposition: Insisting on reparation as consideration for promise to abandon criminal proceedings is a serious abuse of the right of private prosecution; immaterial whether debt real or crime committed if promise exchanged for not prosecuting
precedents.cited_holding: to insist on reparation as a companysideration for promise to abandon criminal proceedings is a, serious abuse of the right of private prosecution. The citizen who proposes to vindicate the criminal law must do so wholeheartedly in the interests of justice, and must number seek his own advantage.

precedents.citation: Kamini Kumar Basu v. Virendra Nath Basu, 1 [1930 L.R. 57 I.A. 117]

anchor.surface_text: In Kamini Kumar Basu v. Virendra Nath Basu, 1 , their Lordships held that ,if it is an implied term of a reference to arbitration, and of an ekrarnama pursuant to an award, that a companyplaint that a number-compoundable offence under the Indian Penal Code has been companymitted shall number be proceeded with, the companysideration is unlawful on the ground of public policy,

precedents.case_name: Kamini Kumar Basu v. Virendra Nath Basu
precedents.cited_proposition: If implied term of arbitration reference that non-compoundable offence complaint shall not be proceeded with, consideration unlawful on public policy grounds, irrespective of whether prosecution commenced
precedents.cited_holding: if it is an implied term of a reference to arbitration, and of an ekrarnama pursuant to an award, that a companyplaint that a number-compoundable offence under the Indian Penal Code has been companymitted shall number be proceeded with, the companysideration is unlawful on the ground of public policy, and the award and ekrarnama are, therefore, unenforceable
